Stratton Executive Director Claire Arctander Deputy Director of Campus Life & Operations carctander@ox-bow.org Ashley Freeby Communications Director & Head Designer afreeby@ox-bow.org Maddie Reyna Education Director mreyna@ox-bow.org In our Office Maggie Bandstra Manager of Ox-Bow House mbandstra@ox-bow.org Steven Berry Consulting Development Director Hannah Bugg Digital Communications Assistant hbugg@ox-bow.org Bobby Gonzales Programs Manager bgonzales@ox-bow.org Christopher Kubik Consulting Business Manager ckubik@ox-bow.org Molly Markow Grants & Relationships Manager mmarkow@ox-bow.org Sally Moeller Bookkeeper smoeller@ox-bow.org Kate Nguyen Community Engagement & Events Manager knguyen@ox-bow.org Kristie Noguera Bookkeeper knoguera@ox-bow.org Candice Whitfield Retail Assistant cwhitfield@ox-bow.org Karen Wentworth Bookkeeper kwentworth@ox-bow.org On Campus Integral to the Ox-Bow experience are the dedicated staff who help define the character of the organization. Ox-Bow has been largely artist run, which infuses the main office, kitchen, maintenance, and housekeeping with a creative and playful sensibility. Below please find the names of our fantastic seasonal staff. Culinary Sabrina Allen Interim Culinary Manager sallen@ox-bow.org RAMA Assistant Culinary Manager rsingleton@ox-bow.org Ren Rodriguez Assistant Culinary Manager rrodriguez@ox-bow.org Baxter Baas Culinary Team Member Cy Brogan Culinary Team Member Joey Drouin Culinary Team Member Court Leonpacher Culinary Team Member Emma Metz Culinary Team Member Erin Paulson Culinary Team Member Frankie Rose Winum Culinary Team Member Facilities John Rossi Facilities Manager jrossi@ox-bow.org Nate Skiffington Assistant Facilities Manager nskiffington@ox-bow.org Zain Sorathia Operations Manager zsorathia@ox-bow.org Office Rowan Leek Campus Manager rleek@ox-bow.org Jon Lewis Campus Office Manager jlewis@ox-bow.org Wellness Joan Wyand Assistant Manager of Campus Life: After Hours and Community Care jwyand@ox-bow.org Housekeeping Aaron Whitfield Housekeeping Manager awhitfield@ox-bow.org Calcifer Strange Housekeeping Assistant Studio Managers Dasha Klein Print & New Media Studio Manager dklein@ox-bow.org Nick Fagan Metals Studio Manager nfagan@ox-bow.org Zena Segre Ceramics Studio Manager zsegre@ox-bow.org Rachel Brace Glass Studio Manager rbrace@ox-bow.org Muskwrat Evans Glass Studio Technician Brett Manski Glass Studio Technician Our Board Ox-Bow's Board of Directors contributes their time, talents, and resources to ensure that future generations of artists will benefit from Ox-Bow's rich tradition and outstanding programming. We are grateful for their dedication and support. President Steven C. Meier MEMBERS Scott Alfree Evan Boris Delinda Collier Christopher Craft Chris Deam Marty Fluhrer Dawn Gavin Keith Goad Loring Randolph jina valentine Keith P. Walker Shauna Wilson Our Emeritus Board Ox-Bow’s Emeritus Board confers special honors and distinction upon former members of Ox-Bow’s Board of Directors and Auxiliary Board who have exhibited noteworthy dedication and commitment to Ox-Bow. This is an appointment that celebrates Ox-Bow’s important legacy. Announces Opening Date for Oxbow Bar & Grill Luminary Hotel & Co. is pleased to announce a March 22 opening date for the hotel’s fifth food and beverage outlet, Oxbow Bar & Grill . Located in what was once known as the City Pier Building (1300 Hendry Street), Oxbow Bar & Grill will bring a new experience to Downtown Fort Myers’ River District, offering a mix of causal dockside dining and shopping designed to ignite a spirit of waterfront adventure. Oxbow will be open daily for lunch and dinner, with brunch on the weekends.... Read More Luminary Hotel & Co Hotel Fact Sheet RECENT ARTICLES Oxbow Press Release – Luminary Hotel & Co. Announces Opening for Oxbow Bar & Grill Follow Us: Join Our Team: Oxbow Job Opportunities 1300 Hendry St Fort Myers, FL 33901 (239) 314-3856 About Gift Cards Contact Careers Diversity Luminary Hotel & Co. No need to spend money on the decor with our jaw-dropping views and beautifully designed interior. Our events specialists look forward to bringing your vision to life! Your guests will revel in the Florida sunshine or spectacular sunsets on our outdoor terrace overlooking the Caloosahatchee. Ideal for added flow during a reception or dramatic flair over a cocktail hour. The separate outdoor staircase adds convenient access and exclusivity. Get In Touch Panoramic Riverfront Views Consider our second floor private event space for your celebration or business program, with 180 degree views of the Caloosahatchee River and sunset. Virtual Tour Drop Us a Line! Our crew would love to hear about your upcoming occasion. Please complete our form below and we’ll be in touch. Fort Myers waterfront restaurants: Oxbow Bar & Grill debuts downtown News Cape Coral Sports Opinion Restaurants Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals FOOD Fort Myers waterfront restaurants: Oxbow Bar & Grill debuts downtown Oxbow Bar & Grill, the latest restaurant from the company behind the Luminary Hotel, has made its waterfront debut in downtown Fort Myers. Here's a look. Annabelle Tometich Fort Myers News-Press At 11 a.m. Monday, March 22, Oxbow Bar & Grill made history, becoming the only riverfront restaurant in the commercial district of downtown Fort Myers. "It is opening day. It's actually opening minute. As of — right now, we are open," Bob Megazzini said shortly after answering his phone last week. The general manager of the Luminary Hotel has seen quite a few opening days in recent months. The 12-story, 243-room property launched in late September, bringing a slew of new food concepts with it. Ella Mae's Diner occupies a far corner of the Luminary's main level, serving classic, thoroughly casual diner fare. There's an onsite coffee shop, Dean Street Coffee Roastery, and, high on the rooftop, Beacon Social Drinkery offers cocktails, small plates and sweeping views. There's a lobby bar, a kitchen theater called The Workshop, and the Luminary's flagship restaurant, Silver King Ocean Brasserie, where stone crab claws and Iberico ham collide with fresh pasta and dry-aged USDA Prime steaks. And, to cap it all off, there is now Oxbow. Looking for a free mini puzzle? Play the USA TODAY Quick Cross now. The new restaurant isn't in the Luminary Hotel. It's over a bridge and across the street. Oxbow occupies the space that formerly housed Art of the Olympians, a space owned by the City of Fort Myers. Oxbow and its parent company, the Tampa-based Mainsail Lodging & Development, won rights to the building in 2017 after edging out the 116-year-old Columbia Restaurant, which is also based in Tampa. Oxbow's 5,000 square feet and 120 seats overlook the Caloosahatchee. MORE: The other front lines: Florida restaurant workers reflect on tumultuous year JLB REVIEW: Finally, a place for mojitos & classic comida Cubana AND: Beacon Social Drinkery stuns, revives from on high "The views are just beautiful," Megazzini said. "If you sit on our decks, you're literally six feet from the water." While the views are stunning, Megazzini said Oxbow's food is meant to be casual. In the hierarchy of Luminary restaurants, Oxbow sits between Ella Mae's and Silver King. Megazzini called it a "casual fine dining experience." Chef Doug Clausing oversees the food side of that experience. Clausing has been with Luminary since its beginning. He launched Beacon Social Drinkery and has now moved his attention to Oxbow, where the dinner menu features smoked chicken wings, deviled eggs with Benton's ham, gumbo with local fish, three styles of oysters and much more. Oxbow's entrees range from a pulled pork sandwich on a brioche bun ($13) to andouille-crusted snapper ($29) and a grilled rib eye cap steak served with potato wedges and chimichurri ($39). Oxbow also features a full bar, including signature craft cocktails. The restaurant opens early on Sundays for brunch. Shannon Bizga, Oxbow's general manager, oversees the restaurant's dining rooms. The property's 2,400-square-foot second floor is designed for private events, though Megazzini said the second-story patio will be open to restaurant guests when possible. The building also features an outfitter-style retail store selling clothing and souvenirs, designed by Boaters Republic, an apparel company based in St. Petersburg. Through the retail space is a U-shaped bar that serves as Oxbow's centerpiece, followed by its open kitchen. "I think we really did hit the mark on every kind of dining in our complex," Megazzini said of the Luminary's five eateries. "This last one has been a long time in the making, and to have it finally here is exciting." Oxbow Bar & Grill is open 11 a.m.-9 p.m. Monday to Wednesday, 11 a.m.-10 p.m. Thursday, 11 a.m.-11 p.m. Friday and Saturday, and 10 a.m.-9 p.m. Sunday at 1300 Hendry St., Fort Myers; call 239-314-3856 or visit oxbowfortmyers.com for reservations and more. Annabelle Tometich writes about food and restaurants for The News-Press, Naples Daily News and USA TODAY Network. (EST) Tel : (269) 857-5811 E-mail : oxbow@ox-bow.org Ox-Bow House 137 Center Street, Douglas, MI 49406 Our Campus & Offices There is no doubt you have questions about how to find our campus. Let us help, get in touch with us! We are more than happy to answer any questions you may have. OX-BOW CAMPUS 3435 Rupprecht Way P.O. Box 216 Saugatuck, MI 49453 Tel : (269) 857-5811 E-mail : oxbow@ox-bow.org Getting to Campus GETTING TO OX-BOW BY CAR FROM CHICAGO: Take I-94 through Indiana and into Michigan just past Benton Harbor. I-94 and 196 split. Take 196/31 north (the sign says To Grand Rapids and Holland). Follow this for 36 miles to the Douglas/Saugatuck exit (Exit 36). Exit a hard right, merging with the Blue Star Highway. Head north to Center Street, where there is a stoplight. Turn west (left) at this stoplight onto Center. At the first cross street, Ferry Street, turn north (right). You will see a golf course on the northwest corner of the intersection. Continue north, passing the road to the city beach (Lincoln). The road you are on (now called Park Street) becomes unpaved before reaching Ox-Bow. You will know you have reached Ox-Bow because the road will end and the entrance to Ox-Bow will begin, i.e. Park Street becomes Ox-Bow's driveway. FROM GRAND RAPIDS: Take 196 west to the Saugatuck /Douglas, Exit 41, turn right off the exit onto the Blue Star Highway. Take the Blue Star Highway (south) to the second stop light and turn right onto Center Street. At the first 4-way stop you reach turn right (north) onto Ferry Street. You will see a golf course on the northwest corner of the intersection. Continue north, passing the road to the city beach (Lincoln). The road you are on (now called Park Street) becomes unpaved before reaching Ox-Bow. You will know you have reached Ox-Bow because the road will end and the entrance to Ox-Bow will begin, i.e. Park Street becomes Ox-Bow's driveway. FROM DETROIT: Take I-94 west to Kalamazoo, then get on 131 north to Grand Rapids. Go about 13 miles on 131 then exit at the Otsego exit towards Allegan. This road is M-89, take it west. Just as you get through Allegan, M-89 will split from M-40 as a left turn. Stay on M-89 through Fennville until you reach the Blue Star Highway. Turn right onto the Blue Star. Highway. Follow it for about five miles until you reach the stop light at Center Street and turn left. At the first cross street, Ferry Street, turn north (right). You will see a golf course on the northwest corner of the intersection. Continue north, passing the road to the city beach (Lincoln). The road you are on (now called Park Street) becomes unpaved before reaching Ox-Bow. You will know you have reached Ox-Bow because the road will end and the entrance to Ox-Bow will begin, i.e. Park Street becomes Ox-Bow's driveway. GETTING TO OX-BOW BY BUS, TRAIN OR PLANE Please call Indian Trails at 800.292.3831 or visit www.indiantrails.com for bus schedules and fares to nearby Holland, Michigan. If you are flying to Ox-Bow, the closest major airport is the Gerald Ford International Airport, in Grand Rapids, located approximately 50 miles from Ox-Bow. Please call Amtrak at 800.USA.RAIL or visit www.amtrak.com for train schedules and fares. For taxi service from the airport in Grand Rapids and train/bus station in Holland, we recommend the Saugatuck-Douglas car service at 269.543.3355. We also recommend visiting our carpool message boards on Doodle to arrange shared rides and taxis. Email oxbow@saic.edu for more information on carpooling. Get in touch with us. Just use the form below and we'll get back to you as soon as we can. Name * First Name Last Name Email Address * Subject * Message * Thank you! Oxbow Bar & Grill is one of the newer additions to the downtown Fort Myers dining scene, and it has something almost no other place in the River District has. Waterfront. And it’s not just a view. In fact, when dining on the outdoor patio, it feels as if you are hovering over the Ca­loosahatchee River, watching the boats float by. Operated by the Luminary Hotel & Co., Oxbow occupies the space once known as the City Pier Building at the Yacht Basin. Bright and airy, its doors opened in March 2021 with a nautical and nostalgic theme, paying homage to the city’s history. Cocktail names make cheeky nods to luminaries such as Thomas Edison. Lit Like Edison has mezcal, pineapple, lime, agave, fee foam and chili spice. Then there is Mccan’t Tell Alice Any­thing , named after Alice Mccan – the city’s first switchboard operator. The tequila-based cocktail has refreshing watermelon, lime, agave and a serrano tincture. It’s served with a flavorful chili and salt rim. Perhaps the best, and the one that sparks the most conversation around the spacious, L-shaped bar is I Don’t Give a F…ort Myers . It’s the bar­tender’s choice. They work with the guest to create something unique and different based on their preference of flavors, spirits and mood. Just in time for Oxbow’s two-year anniversary, the restaurant introduced a new menu. Luminary Hotel marketing manager Ashley Loubier, says, “We had a limited menu after Hurricane Ian as well as limited hours, and we have fi­nally recovered. In the process, we have new chefs and a fantastic new menu.” The offerings are seafood heavy, however, not seafood exclusive. Smoked Fish Dip is an excellent way to start any meal here. The fish is smoked in-house, and the mix can change daily, depending on what the kitchen has available. The dip is served in a jar surrounded by large lavosh crackers and hot sauce for a nice kick. The Tuna Poke Bowl gets rave re­views .Besides chunks of tuna, the bowl is layered with romaine lettuce, hearts of palm and the restau­rant’s signature Carolina Gold Rice. It gets texture from pork rinds and heat from jalapeños. Oysters come raw by the dozen or as part of the Chilled Seafood Platter . It’s an ideal way to try some of everything, in­cluding the fish dip and the poke. Oysters also make a cameo in Gulf Coast Cioppino , along with mussels, lobster, shrimp and chunks of fish. The broth is coconut based, with fennel, hearts of palm and tomato. The sauce is so tempting, you might want to ask for an extra baguette to soak up any that remains. Two popular sandwiches include a Southwest Florida tradition, Grou­per and Swordfish Pastrami . On the pastrami, the meaty fish is topped with house slaw and Swiss cheese. It comes on a pretzel roll. Handhelds also include a signature Oxbow Burger . Truffle cheese is one of the things that sets this apart from most burgers. It’s served on a pretzel roll along with savory mushroom duxelles and sundried tomato aioli. Chicken wings are bone-in, breaded and tossed in a mango chili barbecue glaze. Be sure to ask about the butcher’s cut and the seafood catch of the day. You never know what the chefs have up their sleeves for these daily specials. Plant-based diners are not forgot­ten at Oxbow. The menu has beautiful salads as well as Grilled Cauliflower , and there is nothing typical about it. The cauliflower here sports red chi­michurri sauce, toasted peanuts and blistered tomatoes. Oxbow’s brunch is served on both Saturday and Sunday. It features south­  ern favorites such as fluffy biscuits, creamy grits and Southern Shakshu­ka , a hot dish with okra, pork, tomatoes and eggs. The Quiche is a delightful combination of lump crab, leek and goat cheese. While every seat in the restaurant has a view, the outside seating is popular and noteworthy. Even on warm days, it’s fun to dine on the patio with the powerful fans circulating the air for comfort. A second patio is found upstairs, reserved for special events and private parties. Oxbow also has live music on Thursday and Sunday to add to the ambiance. Check the website and social media for entertainment updates. One of the best parts of Southwest Florida is the water that surrounds the area, and there is nothing quite like din­ing with waterfront scenery. Especially when the ambiance and food are as stel­lar as that found at Oxbow Bar & Grill. Oxbow Bar & Grill is located at 1300 Hendry Street in downtown Fort Myers. Parking is available. There is both indoor and outdoor seating along with private dining and event space. Restaurant hours are Monday through Thursday from 11 a.m. to 10 p.m.; Friday and Saturday from 11 a.m. to 11 p.m.; and Sunday from 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. Saturday and Sunday brunch is served from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Summer hours may vary. Please check the web­site for seasonal hours. Call 239-314- 3856 or visit OxbowFortMyers.com. Our rates are based on 2 adults and 2 children per site (there is maximum of 3 adults allowed per site). Have a question? Checking our availability? We would love to hear from you. Please fill out our form below, or give us a call between 9 am and 8 pm daily at (250) 770-8147 . No RV? Book Our Rental Trailer * THE ASTERISK INDICATES A REQUIRED FIELD. THANK YOU! Please try again. Thanks for your message! We’ll be in touch soon. Join our Newsletter: Oxbow is proud to be anchored within the Luminary Hotel & Co. family. Sign up for their newsletter to chart your course to exclusive offers and events! Sign up Here! Getting Here By Car: Complimentary self-parking spaces are available in front of Oxbow on Hendry Street. Valet parking is available at Luminary Hotel & Co. for a $15 day rate. Self-parking is $1 per hour with a $15 maximum per exit. Additional parking can be found through metered spots on Hendry Street and Edwards Drive. Complimentary Zip Zone parking is on Bay Street and Hendry Street by Ella Mae’s Diner, extending on Hendry away from Luminary Hotel. Getting Here By Boat: While Oxbow does not currently offer boat docking slips, our neighbors at the Fort Myers Yacht Basin do.  Limited spots are available free of charge.  Boaters must call 239-321-7080 or radio the yacht master on channel 16 prior to confirm availability. 1300 Hendry St Fort Myers, FL 33901 (239) 314-3856 About Gift Cards Contact Careers Diversity Luminary Hotel & Co. PRIVATE DINING Our Philosophy Deeply rooted in the Puyallup River Valley, we strive to be a fixture in the community for many years to come. Join us at Oxbow Urban Kitchen for good times, great food and drinks, and many memories to share. We refuse to compromise on quality in our restaurant. That's why we source our fresh ingredients from local farmers' markets. No matter what time of year, you can be sure you're eating the best of the season. Our menu Eat. Drink. Enjoy. ReservationS Reserve Reviews review by - Google & Yelp TOM B ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ Really awesome addition to the area, there's nothing like it in the valley. Good wine list, friendly staff, and a great vibe. The place was completely full on a Sunday night, and we dined at a high-top in the bar (which we prefer anyway!). Oysters were good, pinch buns were tasty, tagliatelle (which we split) was wonderful (and homemade!) and the Brussels were really good. The patio is going to be amazing to dine on once it's open! SHANE E ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ Have been here 2 times now with great food and service. I usually don't expect a new restaurant to run as smoothly as this did. The few staff members that I interacted with were very friendly and knowledgeable about the menu items. My wife loved her cocktails. The restaurant was packed, and it seemed everyone was having a great time. We're excited to sit on the patio when it opens. Looks like it will have multiple fire pit tables! LOUIS R ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ We had a fantastic night. They offered a venison tenderloin which was a treat and excellent. Cooked to perfection. Service was knowledgeable and attentive. The general manager checked on us a couple times. We will definitely go back! JENAH M W ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ Went on opening night! Beautiful building and atmosphere! Drinks were top notch, the bao buns were AMAZING!! I had the steak, it was cooked to perfection, my husband had the Carne asada and it was delicious and great presetation!! DAN Y ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ The building was gorgeous and made for a great overall atmosphere. Our server was polite, tentative, and timely. We ordered the Brussel sprouts and BLT bao buns to start which were both amazing! All I can say is make sure to order these to start- excellent!! Ron E. ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ Great food and even better service. The staff aimed to please! We will definitely tell our friends and be back! Newsletter Sign up for our newsletter & get exclusive offers and invites!
